head.title: May Moves Into Lead In Memphis

hedline.hl1: May Moves Into Lead In Memphis

block.p: Bob May has been here before. That's exactly why he is not ready to get excited over the chance to win his first PGA Tour title.
May shot a two-under-par 69 in windy conditions yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Steve Pate and Notah Begay III after the third round of the St. Jude Classic in Memphis.
Bob May has been here before. That's exactly why he is not ready to get excited over the chance to win his first PGA Tour title.
May shot a two-under-par 69 in windy conditions yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Steve Pate and Notah Begay III after the third round of the St. Jude Classic in Memphis.
But the memory of blowing a third-round lead last October in 40-mile-an-hour winds in the Las Vegas Invitational remains fresh in his mind.
At a T.P.C. at Southwind course where 61 is the record, May said anyone could win the $540,000 check with a good round today.
''The golf course is in perfect shape, and we've got perfect greens,'' he said. ''If someone gets a hot putter, I wouldn't be surprised if someone went out and shot a 64 or 63.''
May, who went through qualifying last year after spending three seasons on the European tour, has as good a chance as anyone to win a tournament that the top money winners have avoided this week.
He has strung together three straight rounds in the 60's for the first time this year. He had six birdies and four bogeys yesterday for a 12-under 201 total after opening with consecutive 66's.
